title: Example code compile failed (macro 'try!')
body:
Linux x64, rustc 1.0.0 (a59de37e9 2015-05-13) (built 2015-05-14)

When compiling examples on page http://doc.rust-lang.org/1.0.0/std/fs/struct.File.html , I got following errors:
work$ cargo build
   Compiling test v0.1.0 
<std macros>:5:8: 6:42 error: mismatched types:
 expected `()`,
    found `core::result::Result<_, _>`
(expected (),
    found enum `core::result::Result`) [E0308]
<std macros>:5 return $ crate:: result:: Result:: Err (
<std macros>:6 $ crate:: convert:: From:: from ( err ) ) } } )
<std macros>:1:1: 6:48 note: in expansion of try!
src/main.rs:5:17: 5:46 note: expansion site
<std macros>:5:8: 6:42 error: mismatched types:
 expected `()`,
    found `core::result::Result<_, _>`
(expected (),
    found enum `core::result::Result`) [E0308]
<std macros>:5 return $ crate:: result:: Result:: Err (
<std macros>:6 $ crate:: convert:: From:: from ( err ) ) } } )
<std macros>:1:1: 6:48 note: in expansion of try!
src/main.rs:6:5: 6:41 note: expansion site
<std macros>:5:8: 6:42 error: mismatched types:
 expected `()`,
    found `core::result::Result<_, _>`
(expected (),
    found enum `core::result::Result`) [E0308]
<std macros>:5 return $ crate:: result:: Result:: Err (
<std macros>:6 $ crate:: convert:: From:: from ( err ) ) } } )
<std macros>:1:1: 6:48 note: in expansion of try!
src/main.rs:8:17: 8:44 note: expansion site
<std macros>:5:8: 6:42 error: mismatched types:
 expected `()`,
    found `core::result::Result<_, _>`
(expected (),
    found enum `core::result::Result`) [E0308]
<std macros>:5 return $ crate:: result:: Result:: Err (
<std macros>:6 $ crate:: convert:: From:: from ( err ) ) } } )
<std macros>:1:1: 6:48 note: in expansion of try!
src/main.rs:10:5: 10:36 note: expansion site
error: aborting due to 4 previous errors
Could not compile `test`.

Source code:

use std::io::prelude::*;
use std::fs::File;

fn main() {
    let mut f = try!(File::create("foo.txt"));
    try!(f.write_all(b"Hello, world!"));

```
let mut f = try!(File::open("foo.txt"));
let mut s = String::new();
try!(f.read_to_string(&mut s));
assert_eq!(s, "Hello, world!");
```

}

Is the example wrong ?
